ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Game development

I learned several critical elements in game making and realized the importance of play-testing. I now know that game design can be taxing and draining after a while, so big respect to all works out there!
Not much.

I was pretty disappointed because I felt like I didnt learn much. Most of the skills that the course promised to teach werent actually taught. I expected to learn a bit more about games, both theory and in practice, but I cant really provide an example of anything I learned.
This course was an amazing experience in the world of games - from their ideation and design all the way to their play testing and enhancement.
I've learned a lot more about what a game is and have gotten better at explaining game design mechanics and planning to create a game.
I learned how to critically analyze games, gameplay, and how to make a game.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: This course is highly collaborative but there are moments of inefficiency.

The strength is that the content of each unit is in-depth and memorable from readings and in class discussions. But the weakness is that I wish either the time distribution for each unit is better-managed or we spend longer in certain units with less units overall.
Didn't learn much, could've been more about game history, game development, or game software.

The most amazing aspect of the course is the freedom given to students with respect to the complexity, focus and collaborative aspects in the games they design - it really allows you to tailor your experience however you want to, and thats so unique and so wonderful. 
Since theres so much freedom, its hard to come up with a weakness - the only one I can think of is three and a half months being too less!

Strengths: A lot of freedom, very enjoyable class discussion (you play games!), and fun assignments
Weaknesses: Some people might struggle because the assignments are generally very open ended and leave room for a lot of creative freedom

Strengths of this course come from its flexibility. The professors were very understanding and flexible with due dates. Furthermore, the interactive nature of the course itself allowed students to have fun playing games but also provided time to engage in critical discussions which I thought was well balanced.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, it gives a good introduction to game design and gets you to work with other people who like games.

Yes! This is a lovely first year seminar that I think anyone who plays video game should take. It not only makes one more appreciative of the process, but also has the potential to make ones imagination come true! The discord server is amazing as well.
Not really, an easy course in which you don't learn much.

No. Perhaps this course was better in past semesters (based on the reviews I read before beginning the class) but I often found myself disappointed. I didnt learn much about gaming software or games at all. We learned a bit of html and css and some twine, but even that I mostly had to look up and teach myself.  I enjoyed game demos, but I wish we had had more time to learn about games in class other than just discussing game demos.
Its an incredible way to explore games and game design - or just a creative art in general - so Id 100% recommend taking it even if you havent been involved in these domains.
Absolutely. Amazing course and a great way to get yourself motivated to start doing game development.

I would highly recommend this course to any first-year student interested in analyzing a wide range of games and who are interested in making their own, (even those without any gaming experience). The class was extremely fun and engaging and opens up your eyes to what goes into designing a game and what constitutes as a game.
